content:
Diagnosis:	Papillary thyroid carcinoma

Management:	15 Jan 2024 Total thyroidectomy and central neck dissection
		12 Feb 2024 Radioactive iodine ablation 100mCi

Histology:	Classical variant papillary thyroid carcinoma, 1.8cm right lobe tumor
		4/12 central compartment nodes positive
		BRAF V600E mutation positive

Current Situation:	Post-treatment assessment

I reviewed [redacted name] today following MDT discussion of her recent whole body iodine scan. The scan shows expected physiological uptake in the thyroid bed with no evidence of residual disease or metastatic foci. Her thyroglobulin has fallen appropriately from 4.2 to 0.8 μg/L on TSH suppression. She is tolerating TSH suppression well with no symptoms of thyrotoxicosis, and her calcium levels have normalized following temporary post-operative hypocalcemia.

At MDT, we reviewed her case in detail including the initial staging, molecular profile, and treatment response. Given her young age of 32, BRAF V600E positive status, and initial nodal involvement, the consensus recommendation is for ongoing TSH suppression targeting TSH <0.1 mU/L for the next 2 years. We will arrange thyroglobulin monitoring every 3 months initially, with neck ultrasound planned for 6 months' time.

I have discussed these recommendations with [redacted name] today. She understands the rationale for ongoing TSH suppression and the importance of medication adherence. She will continue levothyroxine at the current dose of 150mcg daily. We have arranged follow-up in the combined thyroid clinic in 3 months with repeat thyroglobulin measurement and TSH check. I have also provided written information about long-term surveillance protocols and symptoms that should prompt earlier review.
